text: hi everyone healthy bad tano here the
internet's busiest music nerd
and it is time for a review of the new
killers album
imploding the mirage new album from
brandon flowers and the gang
the killers this is album number six
from the band several years after the
underwhelming underwhelming release of
wonderful wonderful
in 2017. given that i've never been the
biggest killers fan in the past
i wasn't even sure what i wanted or was
expecting from this new record
because part of me does honestly feel
like the band has run their course at
this point
it's basically been 20 years as a band
and the killer's progression over this
course of time has been
going from at a very slow pace very
anthemic
overblown new wave and post punk to
very anthemic and overblown heartland
rock which
in my opinion is not exactly the most
exciting move
but at the end of the day the killers do
write some catchy songs and
every new album is good for at least a
few plus i do find brandon flowers to be
one of the most dramatic and captivating
front men
in modern rock when he is on a great
track
oh he's so dreamy
so of course my curiosity got the best
of me i had to see what the killers were
offering
this time around even despite not being
crazy about the singles leading up to
this thing
there's dying breed which is pure
springsteen worship right out of the
born to run era
painfully derivative it points to but
most of my agony on this song
actually comes by way of the chorus
because after listening to this track i
really do feel like a victim
of the loudness war the soaring synth
licks and the grinding bass and the
pounding gated drums are just
beating the lights out of my eardrums
harder
than like a lightning bolt album turned
up to 11. which is sad because i don't
think the tune at the core of this song
is all that bad
the refrain on the hook is absolutely
killer it's righteous it's life
affirming but listening to this
instrumental makes me feel like i am
being suffocated with sound
if that's gonna happen to me my
preferred option
is like droning down tuned guitars
through sun
amps thank you the opener my own soul's
warning at least feels like it has a bit
more room to breathe
at the very least the drums and whaling
synth leads
aren't so busy compositionally and back
off appropriately for the bass-backed
verses
laced with acoustic guitars which
provide a driving and solid groove for
brandon flowers to do his thing vocally
spinning poetic lyrics essentially about
an internal struggle of sorts trying to
trust his instincts while going against
his soul
the compression is still unbearable but
i do chalk the listenability of this
track
up to the instrumentation not doing too
much there is the track
caution which i think is the best single
to drop from this record ahead of time
at least from a songwriting standpoint
anyway you get a sticky verse melody on
this track
along with lyrics that paint an
endearing picture of a girl who's
kind of a firecracker the whole thing is
delivered with this
dylan-esque level of poeticism and
rhythmic flow
of the lyrics too plus you gotta love
i'm throwing caution
what's it gonna be tonight the winds of
change are blowing wild and free
even the production on the track feels
nicely balanced in the first leg of the
song anyway
the drums aren't completely trying to
jackhammer my skull but all bets are off
on the chorus
the volume shoots up and suddenly
there's a lot more reverb
on almost everything so you're not just
dealing with the raw
competing for presence but also the
residue of all the effects
on it like crashing into each other
violently the sound of this track is
really the story of a mix
at war with itself then the track fire
and bone i found to be the oddest
teaser of the bunch it kind of reminds
me of that really awful single from
pearl jam's latest record where they
were doing
a terrible talking heads impersonation
and
yeah the killers are pretty much doing a
talking heads thing here
there is a nocturnal bassy groove on
this track some danceable rhythms and
even brandon flowers vocally embraces
some of david byrne's trademark vocal
tics
it's like listening to a ripoff of
something from speaking in tongues but
then with a god-awful
overly compressed heartland chorus to
boot
and just in concept thinking of these
two musical worlds coming together
is enough to make my stomach churn but
the killers really
made the reality even more nightmarish
than i could have imagined
so yeah on account of these singles i
did not go into this lp with the highest
levels of excitement but you know i was
still intrigued to see katie lang
and wiseblood featured in the tracklist
and i guess one of my favorite modern
artists and songwriters
is collaborating with the killers again
on some of the tracks from this record
alex cameron plus jonathan rado of
foxygen fame had a hand in some of the
production and songwriting too
but despite all of this i didn't find
the deep cuts on this record to be
that much better blowback features one
of the most pleasant mixes on the entire
record
but simultaneously this track brings one
of the mildest
songs on the entire record though i do
find the combination of bubbly
new wave arpeggios and rustic sliding
guitar leads to be sort of cute
meanwhile the song lightning fields
which is as showy and full of pageantry
as a song featuring katie lang
should be you have the glistening
dramatic reverb drenched piano
embellishments the grand
chorus vocals the problem though is this
is the most forgettable song on the
record
making so many chord and progression
changes during the versus any momentum
pre the chorus is just
obliterated the final leg is maybe the
best part of the album though
running towards a place is a slick
nocturnal piece of 80s rock with some
great guitar slinging
the instrumental is a little forceful
but also graceful
vocally brandon flowers is as dramatic
and as passionate as ever
love the linear progression of the
instrumentation and the vocal harmonies
getting more and more intense
as it goes along then there is my god
with wiseblood
top-notch song first off don't talk
to me about forgiveness my god
just look who's back in business plus
the epic choral vocals on the track what
wise blood brings in the second half too
are gorgeous the song and the
instrumental really has a grandiosity to
it that you can
feel and fully appreciate because the
sound is not trying to crush me
but then i find some of the instrumental
theatrics on
when the dreams run dry to be a little
annoying
the island synth leads and the phil
collins-esque drum
fills along with some of the group
shouts and soaring guitar solo harmonies
on the back end
it's not a terrible song but it's so
ornate and so maximal in its
instrumental presentation
that it kind of distracts from how
decent the song is
then the title track the closer is
easily
the best song production on the entire
record like no question by every measure
but the problem is
i don't even feel like going over why
because it's so bittersweet how
too little too late this is like all i
really have to say at this point is
this record in a word is unfortunate
this could have easily been one of the
best
projects the killers have ever put out
but a few song writing duds some
deafening compression
and a lack of artistic identity on a few
tracks as well
kind of derailed any chance of this
being so
feeling a strong four to a light five on
this one
tran position have you given this album
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
